articles.headline: Campaign Puts Trump and the Spy Agencies on a Collision Course
articles.snippet: As president, Donald Trump never trusted the intelligence community. His antipathy has only grown since he left office, with potentially serious implications should he return to power.
articles.abstract: As president, Donald Trump never trusted the intelligence community. His antipathy has only grown since he left office, with potentially serious implications should he return to power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as president, Donald J. Trump flaunted his animosity for intelligence officials, portraying them as part of a politicized “deep state” out to get him. And since he left office, that distrust has grown into outright hostility, with potentially serious implications for national security should he be elected again.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Julian E. Barnes and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: U.S. Targets Unlikely to Be on List in Possible Iranian Attack, Officials Say
articles.snippet: In anticipation of the Iranian strikes, several countries, including the United States, issued new guidelines to their citizens about travel in Israel and the surrounding region.
articles.abstract: In anticipation of the Iranian strikes, several countries, including the United States, issued new guidelines to their citizens about travel in Israel and the surrounding region.
articles.lead_paragraph: American intelligence analysts and officials said on Friday that they expected Iran to strike multiple targets inside Israel within the next few days in retaliation for an Israeli bombing in the Syrian capital on April 1 that killed several senior Iranian commanders.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Farnaz Fassihi, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: The Landline’s Not Dead (at Least at the Masters)
articles.snippet: Augusta National Golf Club has long forbidden cellphones for almost anyone at its hallowed tournament, but patrons delight in making free calls the old-school way.
articles.abstract: Augusta National Golf Club has long forbidden cellphones for almost anyone at its hallowed tournament, but patrons delight in making free calls the old-school way.
articles.lead_paragraph: They call to check in with their bosses or spouses. They call to brag. They call to offer up weather reports, food reviews, golf commentaries, celebrity sightings, souvenir spending confessions, legal advice and trips down memory lane. This year, they called to talk about the solar eclipse.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Doug Mills

articles.headline: Biden’s Student Loan Repayment Plan Is Being Challenged. Here’s What to Know.
articles.snippet: The income-driven plan known as SAVE has reduced payments for millions of borrowers. Lawsuits by Republican-led states are seeking to upend it.
articles.abstract: The income-driven plan known as SAVE has reduced payments for millions of borrowers. Lawsuits by Republican-led states are seeking to upend it.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Biden announced his plan to provide student debt relief for 43 million borrowers nearly two years ago, there was a piece to his program that attracted less attention: a new student loan repayment program that would cut monthly payments in half for millions.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Biden Shrinks Trump’s Edge in Latest Times/Siena Poll
articles.snippet: The president’s popularity has ticked up slightly, though voters still view Donald J. Trump more favorably and have dour views of the economy.
articles.abstract: The president’s popularity has ticked up slightly, though voters still view Donald J. Trump more favorably and have dour views of the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden has nearly erased Donald J. Trump’s early polling advantage, amid signs that the Democratic base has begun to coalesce behind the president despite lingering doubts about the direction of the country, the economy and his age, according to a new survey by The New York Times and Siena College.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: 3 Facts That Help Explain a Confusing Economic Moment
articles.snippet: The path to a “soft landing” doesn’t seem as smooth as it did four months ago. But the expectations of a year ago have been surpassed.
articles.abstract: The path to a “soft landing” doesn’t seem as smooth as it did four months ago. But the expectations of a year ago have been surpassed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic news of the past two weeks has been enough to leave even seasoned observers feeling whipsawed. The unemployment rate fell. Inflation rose. The stock market plunged, then rebounded, then dropped again.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Inside Donald Trump’s Embrace of the Jan. 6 Rioters
articles.snippet: The former president initially disavowed the attack on the Capitol, but he is now making it a centerpiece of his general election campaign.
articles.abstract: The former president initially disavowed the attack on the Capitol, but he is now making it a centerpiece of his general election campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two days before former President Donald J. Trump was booked at an Atlanta jail on his fourth indictment, he held an event at his golf club in New Jersey for another group of people facing criminal charges: rioters accused of storming the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: She Was Kidnapped a Decade Ago With 275 Girls. Finally, She Escaped.
articles.snippet: Their capture set off a global campaign to “Bring Back Our Girls.” But many are still missing, and kidnappings in Nigeria have proliferated.
articles.abstract: Their capture set off a global campaign to “Bring Back Our Girls.” But many are still missing, and kidnappings in Nigeria have proliferated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saratu Dauda had been kidnapped. It was 2014, she was 16, and she was in a truck packed with her classmates heading into the bush in northeastern Nigeria, a member of the terrorist group Boko Haram at the wheel. The girls’ boarding school in Chibok, miles behind them, had been set on fire.
articles.byline: By Ismail Alfa and Ruth Maclean

articles.headline: Dana White, Donald Trump and the Rise of Cage-Match Politics
articles.snippet: White, chief executive of the bloody and beloved Ultimate Fighting Championship, has shot to the peak of Trump-era culture and political influence. What does he want?
articles.abstract: White, chief executive of the bloody and beloved Ultimate Fighting Championship, has shot to the peak of Trump-era culture and political influence. What does he want?
articles.lead_paragraph: Dana White’s diplomatic ambitions were clear, if complicated: Un-cancel Bud Light.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer, Joseph Bernstein and Scott McIntyre

articles.headline: Netflix’s New Film Strategy: More About the Audience, Less About Auteurs
articles.snippet: Dan Lin, the streaming service’s new film chief, wants to produce a more varied slate of movies to better appeal to the array of interests among subscribers.
articles.abstract: Dan Lin, the streaming service’s new film chief, wants to produce a more varied slate of movies to better appeal to the array of interests among subscribers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in, say, 2019, if a filmmaker signed a deal with Netflix, it meant that he or she would be well paid and receive complete creative freedom. Theatrical release? Not so much. Still, the paycheck and the latitude — and the potential to reach the streaming service’s huge subscriber base — helped compensate for the lack of hoopla that comes when a traditional studio opens a film in multiplexes around the world.
articles.byline: By Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: This Prosecutor Pledged to Change George Floyd’s City. Her Critics Are Circling.
articles.snippet: Mary Moriarty, a former chief public defender, became the top prosecutor in Minneapolis, promising an overhaul. Now she faces criticism, including from fellow Democrats.
articles.abstract: Mary Moriarty, a former chief public defender, became the top prosecutor in Minneapolis, promising an overhaul. Now she faces criticism, including from fellow Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mary Moriarty, a former public defender, became Minneapolis’s top prosecutor last year after persuading voters shaken by the murder of George Floyd that she could improve public safety by reining in police misconduct and making the criminal justice system less punitive.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño

articles.headline: Biden Seeks to Head Off Escalation After Israel’s Successful Defense
articles.snippet: The president told Israel that the interception of nearly all of the Iranian drones and missiles used to attack it constituted a major victory, and so further retaliation might not be necessary, U.S. officials said.
articles.abstract: The president told Israel that the interception of nearly all of the Iranian drones and missiles used to attack it constituted a major victory, and so further retaliation might not be necessary, U.S. officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden and his team, hoping to avoid further escalation leading to a wider war in the Middle East, are advising Israel that its successful defense against Iranian airstrikes constituted a major strategic victory that might not require another round of retaliation, U.S. officials said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Iran’s Strikes on Israel Open a Dangerous New Chapter for Old Rivals
articles.snippet: Experts say Tehran does not want a broader war. But it is far from clear whether Iran or Israel will choose to escalate a conflict that has become more direct and out of the shadows.
articles.abstract: Experts say Tehran does not want a broader war. But it is far from clear whether Iran or Israel will choose to escalate a conflict that has become more direct and out of the shadows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iran has retaliated directly against Israel for the killings of its senior generals in Damascus, Syria, with an onslaught of more than 300 drones and missiles aimed at restoring its credibility and deterrence, officials and analysts say.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: On Himalayan Hillsides Grows Japan’s Cold, Hard Cash
articles.snippet: A shrub in impoverished Nepal now supplies the raw material for the bank notes used in Asia’s most sophisticated financial system.
articles.abstract: A shrub in impoverished Nepal now supplies the raw material for the bank notes used in Asia’s most sophisticated financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: The views are spectacular in this corner of eastern Nepal, between the world’s highest mountains and the tea estates of India’s Darjeeling district, where rare orchids grow and red pandas play on the lush hillsides.
articles.byline: By Bhadra Sharma, Alex Travelli and Uma Bista

articles.headline: Why Better Times (and Big Raises) Haven’t Cured the Inflation Hangover
articles.snippet: Frustrated by higher prices, many Pennsylvanians with fresh pay raises and solid finances report a sense of insecurity lingering from the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Frustrated by higher prices, many Pennsylvanians with fresh pay raises and solid finances report a sense of insecurity lingering from the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: In western Pennsylvania, halfway through one of those classic hazy March days when the worst of winter has passed, but the bare trees tilting in the wind tell everyone spring is yet to come, Darren Mattern was putting in some extra work.
articles.byline: By Talmon Joseph Smith

articles.headline: A Show of Might in the Skies Over Israel
articles.snippet: Iran’s retaliation for Israel’s killing of senior military leaders was a highly choreographed spectacle. But fears of a wider war still loom.
articles.abstract: Iran’s retaliation for Israel’s killing of senior military leaders was a highly choreographed spectacle. But fears of a wider war still loom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iran’s much-anticipated retaliation for Israel’s killing of senior military leaders produced a fiery aerial display in the skies over Israel and the West Bank.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Farnaz Fassihi, Aaron Boxerman, Patrick Kingsley and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: U.S. Awards Samsung $6.4 Billion to Bolster Semiconductor Production
articles.snippet: The federal grants will support Samsung’s new chip manufacturing hub in Taylor, Texas, along with the expansion of an existing site in Austin.
articles.abstract: The federal grants will support Samsung’s new chip manufacturing hub in Taylor, Texas, along with the expansion of an existing site in Austin.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration will give up to $6.4 billion in grants to Samsung, one of the world’s largest chipmakers, the latest in a slew of awards intended to shore up domestic production of cutting-edge semiconductors.
articles.byline: By Madeleine Ngo and Don Clark

articles.headline: Tesla Will Lay Off More Than 10% of Workers
articles.snippet: Along with the departure of two senior executives, the cuts added to signs of turmoil at the electric car company.
articles.abstract: Along with the departure of two senior executives, the cuts added to signs of turmoil at the electric car company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Signs of turmoil at Tesla multiplied on Monday after the electric car company told employees it would lay off more than 10 percent of the work force to cut costs and two senior executives resigned.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: A.I. Has a Measurement Problem
articles.snippet: Which A.I. system writes the best computer code or generates the most realistic image? Right now, there’s no easy way to answer those questions.
articles.abstract: Which A.I. system writes the best computer code or generates the most realistic image? Right now, there’s no easy way to answer those questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s a problem with leading artificial intelligence tools like ChatGPT, Gemini and Claude: We don’t really know how smart they are.
articles.byline: By Kevin Roose

articles.headline: With Nuclear Deal Dead, Containing Iran Grows More Fraught
articles.snippet: The U.S., Europe, Russia and China worked together on a 2015 deal to limit Iran’s nuclear program. The arrangement’s unraveling and the spike in superpower tensions make this a dangerous moment.
articles.abstract: The U.S., Europe, Russia and China worked together on a 2015 deal to limit Iran’s nuclear program. The arrangement’s unraveling and the spike in superpower tensions make this a dangerous moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Iran agreed to a deal in 2015 that would require it to surrender 97 percent of the uranium it could use to make nuclear bombs, Russia and China worked alongside the United States and Europe to get the pact done.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger
